plants.notes: Requires staking or caging and consistent watering to prevent blossom end rot.
Pinch flowers regularly to extend leaf production.
Avoid compacted soil to prevent forked roots.
Thrives in dry conditions; overwatering is the most common failure mode.
Requires regular pruning and good air circulation.
Bolts quickly in heat; prefers cool temperatures.
Cold-tolerant and fast-growing; harvest outer leaves first.
One of the fastest crops; uneven watering causes bitterness.
Mulching helps prevent fruit rot and conserves moisture.

plants.notes: Requires acidic soil (pH 4.5–5.5) to thrive.
Hilling soil improves yield and prevents greening.
Known for suppressing soil nematodes.
Requires winter chill hours for proper fruiting.
Improves soil nitrogen availability.
Prefers consistently moist soil and shade.
Prefers dry conditions and good airflow.
Aggressive spreader; best grown in containers.
Highly tolerant of indoor conditions and low light.
Sensitive to frost; often container-grown in cooler climates.
Cold exposure improves bulb formation; avoid excess nitrogen late in growth.

source_metadata.source_name: University of California Agriculture and Natural Resources

plants.notes: Thrives in warm, humid conditions.
Flavor improves after light frost.
Commonly used for hedging and topiary.
Requires consistent moisture and trellising improves air circulation and reduces disease.
Heavy feeder requiring regular harvesting to encourage continued production.
Requires warm soil and protection from wind; benefits from mulching.
Nitrogen-fixing legume; avoid high nitrogen fertilizers.
Cool-season crop; requires consistent moisture and calcium for head development.

plants.notes: Requires blanching (covering heads) to maintain white color; sensitive to temperature fluctuations.
Requires consistent moisture and thinning; greens are edible.
Day-length sensitive; requires sulfur-rich soil for pungency.
Drought-tolerant Mediterranean herb; sensitive to overwatering.
Perennial herb; flavor intensifies when dried; harvest before flowering for best flavor.
Bolts quickly in heat; succession planting recommended; seeds are coriander spice.
Slow to germinate (2-3 weeks); biennial grown as annual; harvest outer leaves first.

source_metadata.source_name: University of California Master Gardener Program

plants.notes: Attracts beneficial insects; does not transplant well; self-seeds readily.
Woody perennial herb; prune regularly to prevent legginess; drought-tolerant once established.
Perennial herb; edible flowers; repels aphids and Japanese beetles.
Allelopathic properties; attracts pollinators and birds; tall varieties require staking.
Excellent cut flower; deadheading promotes continuous blooming; attracts butterflies.
Requires regular deadheading; sensitive to frost; benefits from regular fertilization.
Self-seeding annual; excessive nutrients reduce flowering; attracts beneficial insects.
Edible flowers and leaves; acts as trap crop for aphids; poor soil improves flowering.
Tender perennial often grown as annual; sensitive to overwatering; deadheading prolongs bloom.
Requires warm soil and long growing season; harvest when skin is glossy.
Tolerates light frost; harvest outer leaves first; highly ornamental.
Cool-season crop; bolts in heat; succession planting recommended for continuous harvest.
Cold-hardy; flavor improves after frost; harvest outer leaves first.
Cool-season crop; greens are edible; harvest roots when small for best flavor.
Long growing season; cure after harvest for storage; vine type requires space.
Requires large growing area; harvest when rind is hard; cure for storage.
Requires long warm season and space; reduce watering as fruit matures for sweetness.
Requires warm soil and full sun; reduce watering when fruit ripens; harvest when stem slips easily.
